meta.title: COVID-19 Response - YES Prep Public Schools

meta.name: description
meta.content: COVID-19 Response - YES Prep Public Schools

meta.name: keywords
meta.content: COVID-19 Response, YES Prep Public Schools
COVID-19 Response - YES Prep Public Schools

body.class: fsLiveMode fsHasHeader fsHasMenu fsHasRightBanner fsHasFooter fsHasOneColumnLayout fsSection3908 fsHasTheme2

li.a: Student Handbook and Code of Conduct
Oil & Gas Texas Hold 'Em Poker Tournament
Student Handbook and Code of Conduct

div.p: At YES Prep Public Schools, our priority is the health and safety of our students and staff. We are closely monitoring COVID-19 (coronavirus) and are in communicationwith public health agencies. Wewill update you as information becomes available on this site.
Thank you for your support and cooperation as we continue to prioritize health and safety across YES Prep.

hr.h6: ALL YES PREP SCHOOLS WILL REMAIN CLOSED FOR THE REMAINDER OF THE SCHOOL YEAR.

hr.p: If you need to contact your school for questions, the schoolfront office hours are Monday - Friday,9 a.m. -12 noon. For a list of the schools' main office numbers, click here.
If you are not able to speak to someone, please make sure to leave a message and a staff member will return your call.

div.h6: Haga clic arriba para realizar una breve encuesta. Sus respuestas ayudarn a nuestras escuelas evaluar la eficaz de nuestros esfuerzos y las necesidades de nuestra comunidad. Completar parael lunes, 27 de abril.

hr.p: April 8, 2020 - Message about school closure/Mensaje sobre cierre de escuelas
April 3, 2020 - Message from the Superintendent /Mensaje del Superintendente

div.class: fsDiv fsStyleOneThird fsStyleColumn fsStyleColumn-2 fsStyleColumn-last fsStyleAutoclear

li.a: City of Houston - Health Department's News & Alerts
Harris County Public Health - Latest Facts & Resources
Centers for Disease Control - Info & Updates

div.p: As always, the 211 Texas/United Way HELPLINE is providinginformation about community resources and connectingpeople to basic needs assistance and other social services, for which demand is likely to increase.
You can also search the 211 database online athttp://referral.unitedwayhouston.org/.
211 is not the number to call for emergencies or if someone suspects they have COVID-19.
Currently, all Legacy clinics for medical and behavioral health are open for service. (Click here for PDF of clinic location map.)

li.em: Although schools are closed at this time, Legacy School Based Health Clinics are still open and able to take care of medical and behavioral health needs from the comfort of yourhome. (Click here for a bilingual flyer with more information.)

div.p: If you need additional support, get support regarding your anxiety or stress by speaking to a trained counselor at SAMHSA Disaster Distress
Helpline at 1-800-985-5990 or by texting TalkWithUS 66746.
For more information, visit Legacy Community Health's website.

img.alt: First page of the PDF file: AllClinicLocationsPageENGSPAN85x112020FINALMARGINS

div.p: Harris Health System's "Ask My Nurse"

Ask My Nurse line will provide help with access for symptoms assessments and referral to appropriate levels of care in a clinical setting. Harris County will also staff a call line with public health staff who will be available to answer questions from the general public about coronavirus disease (COVID-19).

Residents without access to healthcare can call the triage line for COVID-19-related questions at 713-634-1110 from 9 a.m. - 7 p.m., sevendays a week. Nurses will be available to provide care in both English and Spanish.
To learn more, visit Ask My Nurse website.

div.strong: City of Houston's COVID-19 Call Center

div.p: Call the HoustonHealth Department with your COVID-19 questions and to be screened for Houston's community based testing site.

M-F: 9 a.m. - 7 p.m.
Sat: 9 a.m. - 3 p.m.
To learn more,visit the City of Houston's Coronavirus Disease 2019 website.

p.strong: Free breakfast and lunch meals starting March 23

div.p: YES Prep Public Schools will be providing a breakfast and lunch meal daily at no cost to all children 18 and under in our communities starting Monday, March 23 until classes resume again. Pickup locations will be at all YES Prep non-partnership campuses from 10 11a.m.
All partnership campus students (Hoffman, Eisenhower, Northbrook Middle and Northbrook High schools) can also pick up meals at any of the 15 locations.
For more information, click here.

Houston Food Bank (HFB) is a valued community partner. Working to eliminate food insecurity, Houston Food Bank provides a Mobile Food Pantry on several campuses monthly and complete weekend meals to students throughout the district. With the citys focus on Coronavirus, HFB isprovidingMeals on Wheels to individuals and families required to quarantine as a result of the emergency.
If you are in need of the service, call the HFB help line at 832.369.9390.
If you are not quarantined and need to find a pantry near you, visit https://www.houstonfoodbank.org/covid19/.

The Houston Parks and Recreation Department's Curbside Meal Program for Youth, ages 1 to 18, is distributinga snack and lunchMonday Friday from 1 3p.m. Atotal of 50 meals will be available at each site.To ensure social distancing is maintained throughout the curbside meal distribution, meals will be placed in the trunk of the recipients car.
For more information and list of locations, click here.

The City of Houston has put together lists of food resources for seniors, families, children, and people with disabilities. Click here to access the document.
To get assistance with applying for SNAP, you can contact the Houston Food Banks Community Assistance Program at 832-369-9390.
For meal delivery, seniors can contact Harris County Precinct 2s meal program at 713-274-2222.

YES Prep has partnered with EveryoneOnto provide families with the best low-cost internet service and computer offers during this challenging time. By clicking on link below and entering your zipcode,you'll find low-cost internet service and computers in your area.
Click here for more details.

p.a: Region 4 Support for COVID-19 | Internet Access for Students at Home

hr.p: Region 4 Education Service Center (Region 4) is here to support you. Check out this site to see how companies like Comcast, Verizon, Sprint and more are supporting students and their families. Service providers will provide free/low cost internet to families or have pledged to refrain from disconnecting services due to non-payment during the COVID-19 pandemic.

In response to the Coronavirus (COVID-19) emergency, Internet Essentials has increased speeds to 25/3 Mbps for all customers - no action is required.In addition, new customers will receive two months of free service.Click herefor more details.

UPDATE: Until further notice, all Xfinity WiFi Public Hotspots are now open to everyone on the xfinitywifi SSID. Public hotspots can be found in small/medium businesses and outdoors in commercial areas. Non-Xfinity subscribers need to accept Terms and Conditions to access the network and repeat when requested to continue to receive free unlimited access. Please refer to the map below for available public hotspots." You can enter your zip to find a nearby hotspot.
Guide to Internet Service During New Coronavirus (COVID-19) Outbreak.
From the FCC site, you can also see a list of companies going above and beyond.
Most have special considerations for low-income customers and for educators and students.

li.a: What you need to know about COVID-19
Talking to your child about COVID-19
Coping in Hard Times: Fact Sheet for Parents
Parent/Caregiver Guide to Helping Families Cope With COVID-19

h2.a: What you need to know about COVID-19

img.alt: First page of the PDF file: 2019-ncov-factsheet
First page of the PDF file: 2019-ncov-factsheet-sp
First page of the PDF file: 2019-ncov-factsheet-chinese

h2.a: Talking to your child about COVID-19

div.p: A new type of coronavirus, abbreviated COVID-19, is causing an outbreak of respiratory (lung) disease. It was first detected in China and has now been detected internationally. While the immediate health risk in the United States is low, it is important to plan for any possible outbreaks if the risk level increases in the future.

Concern over this new virus can make children and families anxious. While we dont know where and to what extent the disease may spread here in the United States, we do know that it is contagious, that the severity of illness can vary from individual to individual, and that there are steps we can take to prevent the spread of infection. Acknowledging some level of concern, without panicking, is appropriate and can result in taking actions that reduce the risk of illness. Helping children cope with anxiety requires providing accurate prevention information and facts without causing undue alarm.

It is very important to remember that children look to adults for guidance on how to react to stressful events. If parents seem overly worried, childrens anxiety may rise. Parents should reassure children that health and school officials are working hard to ensure that people throughout the country stay healthy. However, children also need factual, age appropriate information about the potential seriousness of disease risk and concrete instruction about how to avoid infections and spread of disease. Teaching children positive preventive measures, talking with them about their fears, and giving them a sense of some control over their risk of infection can help reduce anxiety.

ul.li: Children will react to and follow your verbal and nonverbal reactions.
What you say and do about COVID-19, current prevention efforts, and related events can either increase or decrease your childrens anxiety.
If true, emphasize to your children that they and your family are fine.
Remind them that you and the adults at their school are there to keep them safe and healthy.
Let your children talk about their feelings and help reframe their concerns into the appropriate perspective.
Children may need extra attention from you and may want to talk about their concerns, fears, and questions.
It is important that they know they have someone who will listen to them; make time for them.
Tell them you love them and give them plenty of affection.
When tensions are high, sometimes we try to blame someone.
It is important to avoid stereotyping any one group of people as responsible for the virus.
Bullying or negative comments made toward others should be stopped and reported to the school.
Be aware of any comments that other adults are having around your family. You may have to explain what comments mean if they are different than the values that you have at home.

p.strong: Monitor television viewing and social media.

ul.li: Limit television viewing or access to information on the Internet and through social media. Try to avoid watching or listening to information that might be upsetting when your children are present.
Speak to your child about how many stories about COVID-19 on the Internet may be based on rumors and inaccurate information.
Talk to your child about factual information of this diseasethis can help reduce anxiety.
Constantly watching updates on the status of COVID-19 can increase anxietyavoid this.
Be aware that developmentally inappropriate information (i.e., information designed for adults) can cause anxiety or confusion, particularly in young children.
Engage your child in games or other interesting activities instead.

p.strong: Maintain a normal routine to the extent possible.

ul.li: Keep to a regular schedule, as this can be reassuring and promotes physical health.
Encourage your children to keep up with their schoolwork and extracurricular activities, but dont push them if they seem overwhelmed.
In the absence of factual information, children often imagine situations far worse than reality.
Dont ignore their concerns, but rather explain that at the present moment very few people in this country are sick with COVID-19.
Children can be told this disease is thought to be spread between people who are in close contact with one anotherwhen an infected person coughs or sneezes.
It is also thought it can be spread when you touch an infected surface or object, which is why it is so important to protect yourself.
For additional factual information contact your school nurse, ask your doctor, or check the https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/index.html website.
The CDC believes these symptoms appear in a few days after being exposed to someone with the disease or as long as 14 days after exposure: o Fever o Cough o Shortness for breath

For some people the symptoms are like having a cold; for others they are quite severe or even life threatening. In either case it is important to check with your childs healthcare provider (or yours) and follow instructions about staying home or away from public spaces to prevent the spread of the virus.

p.strong: Review and model basic hygiene and healthy lifestyle practices for protection.

ul.li:
Encourage your child to practice every day good hygienesimple steps to prevent spread of illness: o Wash hands multiple times a day for at least 20 seconds (singing Twinkle, Twinkle Little Star slowly takes about 20 seconds).
Cover their mouths with a tissue when they sneeze or cough and throw away the tissue immediately, or sneeze or cough into the bend of their elbow. Do not share food or drinks.
Practice giving fist or elbow bumps instead of handshakes. Fewer germs are spread this way.
Giving children guidance on what they can do to prevent infection gives them a greater sense of control over disease spread and will help to reduce their anxiety.
Encourage your child to eat a balanced diet, get enough sleep, and exercise regularly; this will help them develop a strong immune system to fight off illness.

p.strong: Discuss new rules or practices at school.

ul.li: Many schools already enforce illness prevention habits, including frequent hand washing or use of alcohol-based hand cleansers.
Your school nurse or principal will send information home about any new rules or practices.
Be sure to discuss this with your child.
Contact your school nurse with any specific questions.

Let your school know if your child is sick and keep them home. Your school may ask if your child has a fever or not. This information will help the school to know why your child was kept home. If your child is diagnosed with COVID-19, let the school know so they can communicate with and get guidance from local health authorities.

Talk to your school nurse, school psychologist, school counselor, or school social worker if your child is having difficulties as a result of anxiety or stress related to COVID-19. They can give guidance and support to your child at school.
Make sure to follow all instructions from your school.

div.p: You know your children best. Let their questions be your guide as to how much information to provide. However, dont avoid giving them the information that health experts identify as critical to ensuring your childrens health. Be patient; children and youth do not always talk about their concerns readily. Watch for clues that they may want to talk, such as hovering around while you do the dishes or yard work. It is very typical for younger children to ask a few questions, return to playing, then come back to ask more questions.

When sharing information, it is important make sure to provide facts without promoting a high level of stress, remind children that adults are working to address this concern, and give children actions they can take to protect themselves.
Information is rapidly changing about this new virusto have the most correct information stay informed by accessing https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/index.html.

ul.li: Early elementary school children need brief, simple information that should balance COVID-19 facts with appropriate reassurances that their schools and homes are safe and that adults are there to help keep them healthy and to take care of them if they do get sick. Give simple examples of the steps people take every day to stop germs and stay healthy, such as washing hands. Use language such as adults are working hard to keep you safe.

Upper elementary and early middle school children will be more vocal in asking questions about whether they truly are safe and what will happen if COVID-19 comes to their school or community. They may need assistance separating reality from rumor and fantasy. Discuss efforts of school and community leaders to prevent germs from spreading.

Upper middle school and high school students are able to discuss the issue in a more in-depth (adult-like) fashion and can be referred directly to appropriate sources of COVID-19 facts. Provide honest, accurate, and factual information about the current status of COVID-19. Having such knowledge can help them feel a sense of control.

p.strong: Suggested Points to Emphasize When Talking to Children

ul.li: Adults at home and school are taking care of your health and safety. If you have concerns, please talk to an adult you trust. Not everyone will get the coronavirus (COVID-19) disease. School and health officials are being especially careful to make sure as few people as possible get sick.
It is important that all students treat each other with respect and not jump to conclusions about who may or may not have COVID-19.

There are things you can do to stay health and avoid spreading the disease:
Avoid close contact with people who are sick.
Stay home when you are sick.
Cover your cough or sneeze into your elbow or a tissue, then throw the tissue in the trash.
Avoid touching your eyes, nose, and mouth.
Wash hands often with soap and water (20 seconds).
If you dont have soap, use hand sanitizer (6095% alcohol based).
Clean and disinfect frequently touched objects and surfaces using a regular household cleaning spray or wipe.

div.p: Talking With Children: Tips for Caregivers, Parents, and Teachers During Infectious Disease Outbreaks, https://store.samhsa.gov/product/Talking-With-Children-Tips-for-Caregivers-Parents-andTeachers-During-Infectious-Disease-Outbreaks/SMA14-4886
Coping With Stress During Infectious Disease Outbreaks, https://store.samhsa.gov/product/Copingwith-Stress-During-Infectious-Disease-Outbreaks/sma14-4885
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19), https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/about/transmission.html
Handwashing and Hand Sanitizer Use at Home, at Play, and Out and About, https://www.cdc.gov/handwashing/pdf/hand-sanitizer-factsheet.pdf

p.em: For more information related to schools and physical and mental health, visit www.nasponline.org and www.nasn.org.

div.pre: 2020, National Association of School Psychologists, 4340 East West Highway, Suite 402, Bethesda, MD 20814, 301-657-0270

div.h2: Hable con sus hijos sobre el COVID-19 (Coronavirus)
div.p: Un nuevo tipo de coronavirus, abreviado COVID-19, est causando un brote de enfermedades respiratorias (pulmonares). Se detect por primera vez en China y ahora se ha detectado a nivel internacional. Si bien el riesgo inmediato para la salud en los Estados Unidos es bajo, es importante estar preparados para posibles brotes si el nivel de riesgo aumenta en el futuro.

La preocupacin a causa de este nuevo virus puede provocar ansiedad en los nios y las familias. Aunque no sabemos dnde y en qu medida puede propagarse la enfermedad aqu en los Estados Unidos, s sabemos que es contagiosa, que la gravedad de la enfermedad puede variar de una persona a otra y que hay medidas que podemos tomar para prevenir la propagacin de la infeccin. Aceptar un cierto nivel de preocupacin, sin entrar en pnico, es adecuado y puede conducirnos a tomar medidas que reduzcan el riesgo de contagio. Ayudar a los nios a lidiar con la ansiedad requiere proporcionar informacin y datos precisos sobre la prevencin sin darles motivos para alarmarse innecesariamente.

Es muy importante recordar que los nios buscan orientacin en los adultos sobre cmo reaccionar ante eventos estresantes. Si los padres parecen excesivamente preocupados, la ansiedad de los nios puede aumentar. Los padres deben asegurar a los nios que las autoridades escolares y de salud estn trabajando arduamente para garantizar que todas las personas del pas sigan estando sanas. Sin embargo, los nios tambin necesitan informacin objetiva y adecuada para su edad sobre la posible gravedad del riesgo de la enfermedad e indicaciones concretas sobre cmo evitar infecciones y la propagacin de la enfermedad. Ensear a los nios medidas preventivas positivas, hablar con ellos sobre sus miedos y brindarles una sensacin de cierto control sobre su riesgo de contagio puede ayudar a reducir la ansiedad.

p.strong: Conserve la calma y la tranquilidad.

ul.li: Los nios reaccionarn, y copiarn sus reacciones verbales y no verbales.
Lo que dice y hace respecto del COVID-19, los esfuerzos actuales de prevencin, y los eventos relacionados pueden aumentar o disminuir la ansiedad de sus hijos.
Si es cierto, comunique con nfasis a sus hijos que ellos y su familia estn bien.
Recurdeles que usted y los adultos de su escuela estn a su lado para mantenerlos sanos y salvos.
Deje que sus hijos hablen sobre sus sentimientos y ayude a redefinir sus inquietudes hacia la perspectiva correcta.
Es posible que los nios necesiten mayor atencin de su parte, y deseen hablar sobre sus inquietudes, miedos y preguntas.
Es importante que sepan que cuentan con alguien que los escuchar; reserve tiempo para estar con ellos.
Dgales que los ama y brndeles mucho afecto.
Cuando estamos muy tensos, a veces intentamos culpar a alguien.
Es importante no estereotipar a un grupo de personas como responsables del virus.
El acoso escolar y los comentarios negativos sobre otras personas deben detenerse e informarse a la escuela.

Est atento a cualquier comentario que otros adultos realicen en el entorno de su familia. Es posible que deba explicar qu significan dichos comentarios si son diferentes de los valores que ensea en su hogar.

p.strong: Controle el uso de la televisin y las redes sociales.

ul.li: Limite el tiempo destinado a ver televisin o el acceso a informacin en Internet y a travs de las redes sociales. Trate de evitar ver o escuchar informacin que pueda ser desconcertante cuando sus hijos estn presentes.
Hable con su hijo sobre la posibilidad de que muchas historias sobre el COVID-19 en Internet pueden estar basadas en rumores e informacin incorrecta.
Brinde a su hijo informacin objetiva acerca de esta enfermedad, esto puede ayudar a reducir la ansiedad.
Estar constantemente pendiente de las novedades sobre el estado del COVID-19 puede aumentar la ansiedad; evite hacer esto.
Tenga en cuenta que la informacin inadecuada para el nivel de desarrollo de los nios (es decir, informacin diseada para adultos) puede causar ansiedad o confusin, particularmente en nios pequeos.
En cambio, haga que su hijo participe en juegos u otras actividades interesantes.

p.strong: Mantenga una rutina normal en la medida de lo posible.

ul.li: Ajstese a un programa regular, ya que esto puede resultar tranquilizador y promueve la salud fsica.
Motive a sus hijos a mantenerse al da con sus tareas escolares y actividades extracurriculares, pero no los obligue si parecen agobiados.
Ante la falta de informacin objetiva, a menudo los nios imaginan situaciones mucho peor que la realidad.
No ignore sus inquietudes; explqueles que en este momento muy pocas personas en este pas estn enfermas con COVID-19.
Puede decirles a los nios que se cree que esta enfermedad se contagia entre personas que estn muy cerca una de otra, cuando una persona infectada tose o estornuda.
Tambin se cree que puede contagiarse cuando se toca una superficie o un objeto infectados, por eso es tan importante protegerse.
Para obtener ms informacin objetiva, comunquese con el personal de enfermera de su escuela, consulte con su mdico o visite el sitio web https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/index.html.

Los Centros para el Control y la Prevencin de Enfermedades (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, CDC) consideran que estos sntomas aparecen unos pocos das despus de haber estado expuesto a alguien con la enfermedad o hasta 14 das despus de la exposicin: o Fiebre o Tos o Dificultad para respirar

Para algunas personas, los sntomas son similares a tener un resfro; para otras, son bastante graves o incluso potencialmente mortales. En cualquier caso, es importante que consulte con el proveedor de atencin mdica de su hijo (o de usted) y siga las indicaciones sobre permanecer en el hogar o lejos de espacios pblicos para prevenir la propagacin del virus.

p.strong: Revise y ponga en prctica hbitos de higiene bsicos y un estilo de vida saludable como forma de proteccin.

ul.li:
Aliente a su hijo a practicar cada da una buena higiene; pasos simples para prevenir la propagacin de la enfermedad:
Lavarse las manos varias veces al da durante al menos 20 segundos (cantar Estrellita, dnde ests? lentamente lleva alrededor de 20 segundos).
Cubrirse la boca con un pauelo de papel al toser o estornudar y desecharlo de inmediato, o estornudar o toser en la curva del codo. No compartir alimentos ni bebidas.
Practicar el choque de puos o de codos en lugar de dar apretones de manos. De esta manera, se propagan menos grmenes.
Orientar a los nios sobre lo que pueden hacer para prevenir una infeccin les brinda una mayor sensacin de control sobre el contagio de la enfermedad y les ayudar a reducir su nivel de ansiedad.
Motive a su hijo a llevar una dieta equilibrada, dormir lo suficiente y hacer ejercicio en forma regular; esto le ayudar a desarrollar un sistema inmunolgico fuerte para combatir enfermedades.

p.strong: Converse sobre nuevas reglas o prcticas en la escuela.

ul.li: Muchas escuelas ya hacen cumplir hbitos para prevenir enfermedades, que incluyen lavarse las manos con frecuencia o usar productos de limpieza para manos a base de alcohol.
El personal de enfermera o el director de su escuela enviarn informacin al hogar acerca de cualquier regla o prctica nueva.
Asegrese de conversar sobre esto con su hijo.
Comunquese con el personal de enfermera de su escuela si tiene alguna pregunta especfica.

Avise a la escuela si su hijo est enfermo y mantngalo en casa. Es posible que su escuela le pregunte si su hijo tiene fiebre o no. Esta informacin ayudar a la escuela a saber por qu su hijo se qued en casa. Si a su hijo se le diagnostica COVID-19, informe a la escuela para que pueda comunicarse con las autoridades sanitarias locales y recibir orientacin.

Hable con el personal de enfermera de su escuela, el psiclogo escolar, el consejero escolar o el trabajador social de la escuela si su hijo tiene dificultades motivadas por ansiedad o estrs relacionadas con el COVID-19. Estas personas pueden brindarle orientacin y apoyo a su hijo en la escuela.
Asegrese de seguir todas las indicaciones de su escuela.

div.p: Nadie conoce mejor a sus hijos que usted. Deje que sus preguntas lo guen respecto de cunta informacin brindar. Sin embargo, no evite darles la informacin que los expertos en salud identifican como fundamental para garantizar la salud de sus hijos. Sea paciente; los nios y adolescentes no siempre hablan acerca de sus inquietudes con facilidad. Est atento ante comportamientos que indiquen que desean hablar, por ejemplo, si dan vueltas cuando lava los platos o trabaja en el jardn. Es muy habitual en nios ms pequeos hacer algunas preguntas, volver a jugar y luego regresar a hacer ms preguntas.

Al compartir informacin, es importante asegurarse de proporcionar datos sin promover un alto nivel de estrs, recordarles a los nios que los adultos estn trabajando para solucionar su inquietud y brindarles medidas que pueden tomar para protegerse.
La informacin sobre este nuevo virus cambia rpidamente; para obtener la mayor cantidad de informacin correcta, mantngase al tanto ingresando a https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/index.html.

p.strong: Procure que las explicaciones sean adecuadas para la edad

ul.li: Los nios en los primeros aos de escuela primaria necesitan informacin breve y simple que debe equilibrar datos sobre el COVID-19 con la debida tranquilidad de que sus escuelas y hogares estn a salvo, y de que los adultos estn a su lado para mantenerlos sanos y cuidar de ellos si se enferman. Brinde ejemplos sencillos de las medidas que la gente toma todos los das para eliminar grmenes y mantenerse sana, como lavarse las manos. Use expresiones como los adultos estamos trabajando mucho para que estn a salvo.

Los nios en los ltimos aos de la escuela primaria y los primeros aos de la educacin media sern ms expresivos al hacer preguntas acerca de si realmente estn a salvo y qu suceder si el COVID-19 llega a su escuela o comunidad. Es posible que necesiten ayuda para diferenciar la realidad de los rumores y la fantasa. Explique los esfuerzos de dirigentes escolares y comunitarios para prevenir la propagacin de grmenes.

Los estudiantes en los ltimos aos de la escuela media y la escuela secundaria pueden conversar sobre el asunto con mayor profundidad (como adultos) y se los puede remitir directamente a fuentes apropiadas de informacin sobre el COVID-19. Proporcione informacin honesta, precisa y objetiva sobre el estado actual del COVID-19. Dicho conocimiento puede ayudarles a tener una sensacin de control.

p.strong: Puntos que se aconseja enfatizar al hablar con nios

ul.li: Los adultos en casa y en la escuela estn protegiendo tu salud y seguridad. Si algo te preocupa, habla con un adulto de confianza.

No todas las personas contraern la enfermedad del coronavirus (COVID-19). Las autoridades escolares y de salud trabajan con mucho cuidado para asegurarse de que se enferme la menor cantidad de personas posible.
Es importante que todos los estudiantes se traten con respeto y no saquen conclusiones sobre quin puede o no tener el COVID-19.

Hay cosas que puedes hacer para mantenerte sano y evitar la propagacin de la enfermedad:
Evita el contacto muy prximo con personas enfermas.
Qudate en casa cuando ests enfermo.
Al toser o estornudar, cbrete la boca con el codo o un pauelo de papel, luego tira el pauelo a la basura.
Evita tocarte los ojos, la nariz y la boca. o Lvate las manos frecuentemente con jabn y agua (durante 20 segundos).
Si no tienes jabn, utiliza desinfectante para manos (60 % a 95 % de alcohol).
Limpia y desinfecta los objetos y las superficies que se tocan con mayor frecuencia con un aerosol o pao de limpieza para el hogar.

div.p: Consejos sobre cmo hablar con los nios: Consejos para los cuidadores, padres y maestros durante un brote de una enfermedad contagiosa, https://store.samhsa.gov/product/Talking-With-Children-Tipsfor-Caregivers-Parents-and-Teachers-During-Infectious-Disease-Outbreaks/SMA14-4886
Cmo lidiar con el estrs durante un brote de una enfermedad contagiosa, https://store.samhsa.gov/product/Coping-with-Stress-During-Infectious-Disease-Outbreaks/sma14-4885
Centros para el Control y la Prevencin de Enfermedades, Enfermedad del Coronavirus 2019 (COVID19), https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/about/transmission.html

Handwashing and Hand Sanitizer Use at Home, at Play, and Out and About (Lavado de manos y uso de desinfectantes para manos en el hogar, durante juegos y paseos), https://www.cdc.gov/handwashing/pdf/hand-sanitizer-factsheet.pdf

p.em: Para obtener ms informacin relacionada con las escuelas, y la salud fsica y mental, visite www.nasponline.org y www.nasn.org.

div.pre: 2020, National Association of School Psychologists, 4340 East West Highway, Suite 402, Bethesda, MD 20814, 301-657-0270
